awd_titl_txt: Quantum Computational Complexity of Classical Statistical Mechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
The computational advantages of Quantum Information Processing in the context of
classical statistical mechanics are still largely unknown. This proposal is concerned with understanding the power of quantum computation in the context of hard classical statistical mechanics problems. This will be done by developing a classification of which instances of the Ising Spin Glass and Potts models (key models in statistical mechanics) are amenable to fast quantum simulation. It is expected that this will lead directly to an understanding of the quantum computational complexity of related problems in combinatorics, graph theory, knot theory, and topology. Thus this proposal aims to shed light on the border between classical and quantum computational complexity theory, beyond the existing variants on Shors and Grovers algorithms. Two distinct approaches will be pursued: (i) The use of coding theory and an exisiting quantum algorithm for number-theoretic objects known as Gauss sums, and (ii) A representation of quantum circuits in terms of an algebraic object known as quadratically signed weight enumerators. In both cases a direct connection can be made to the partition function of the Potts model or the Ising Spin Glass model, which
are known to generate computationally hard problems. The basic approach to be
pursued is to classify instances of these two models in terms of their quantum
computational complexity. This will shed light on the power of quantum computation, and may lead to the discovery of new quantum algorithms which outperform their classical counterparts. Broad Impact: This proposal will promote training, and learning in quantum computation. Quantum computation has potential for dramatic impact on ab initio materials and drug design. This proposal aims to elucidate the potential of quantum computation in simulating classical physics, which can benefit society by providing fast solutions to hard classical statistical mechanics problems arising, e.g., in polymer physics, and fields requiring combinatorial optimization. The PI is the Director
of the newly formed Center for Quantum Information Science & Technology (CQIST) at USC, which will coordinate outreach activities aimed at socioeconomically challenged as well as gifted students in the Los Angeles area. It will build a University home base for science teachers at high schools in central Los Angeles. CQIST will disseminate the results of the research of this proposal, by means of publications, regular series of meetings, and contacts with the press.

por.por_cntn:
This project, which resulted in nine published papers, contributed to several distinct subdisciplines of mathematical physics. A summary of four representative works follows.

In the project that is most closely related to the original proposal, we probed the limits of the power of quantum computers. While most work on quantum computation focuses on which problems can be solved more efficiently than on classical computers, the complementary perspective is equally important: which problems cannot be solved more efficiently on quantum computers than on their classical counterparts? We identified a class of such problems originating in classical statistical mechanics, in particular certain interacting 
spin systems, whose crucial defining feature is the type of graph they occupy.

In a second project we addressed the problem of optimal quantum error correcting codes. This task is essential to protect quantum computers against error resulting from their inevitable interaction with their environment. If left unchecked such an interaction will rob quantum computers of any advantage over classical computers. Our approach was to assume that an experimenter has characterized the error channel via a procedure known as quantum process tomography. Armed with this knowledge we showed how one can design quantum error correcting codes tailored to a given noise channel by casting the problem in terms of a bi-convex optimization problem for the encoding and recovery procedures. The procedures we found are robust against variations in the error channel. 

In a third project we solved an old open problem in the theory of quantum open systems. These are, by definition, systems undergoing an interaction with an environment (as in the quantum error correction problem mentioned above), and the problem we addressed and solved is the general problem of characterizing their dynamics in terms of maps from the initial to the final system state. We gave a general classification of such maps, showing that they are always linear, and found necessary and sufficient conditions for them to assume a particularly important form known as completely positive (CP). CP maps are the work horse of much of quantum information processing, and prior to our work only sufficient conditions were known for their applicability. We showed that as long as the initial system-environment is purely classically correlated (in the sense of a measure known as the quantum discord), the resulting open system dynamics can be described by a CP map. Moreover, this condition is also necessary. 

In the fourth project, we studied the effect of spatial boundary conditions on entanglement. Entanglement is a non-classical correlation that can develop between two or more quantum systems, and is believed to play a key role in the power of quantum information processing. We wanted to know what happens to entanglement when two quantum systems are separated by a fractal boundary. The motivation here was to understand whether this would lead to anomalous scaling of the entanglement between the two systems. We found this to indeed be the case, in the sense that we have a non-integer scaling of entanglement with the length of the boundary. This constitutes the first example of 'fractal entanglement'.
